Award.AwardTitle: Merging Agent-based Modeling Techniques and Ethnography: A New Analytic Tool for Studying Illicit Drug Use Behaviors, Markets and Economies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Lee D. Hoffer, will undertake research on the simulation of the operation of a local illegal drug market by synthesizing ethnographic decision tree and Agent-Based Modeling (ABM) techniques as an innovative strategy for improving ethnographic analysis and utilization. The specific aims of this research are to: 1) conduct an ethnographic study of the local market that facilitates ABM development, 2) enrich these data using Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) technologies, and 3) construct a social / economic simulation computer simulation that reproduces how the market operates.

Complexity Theory suggests social structures emerge from non-linear interactions of heterogeneous actors changing, and being changed by, their environment. Investigating the emergent and dynamic social structures of a local drug market using ABM, the intellectual merits of this study involve the practical application of Complexity Theory in social science. While theoretical demonstrations of emergence using ABM are common, well articulated methods for real-world research applications of social simulation in anthropology are scarce. This project provides a framework for conducting experiments with findings from ethnographic fieldwork enhancing both the analytic and descriptive capabilities of the methodology. Constructing simulations representing results also expands the utility of ethnography to policymakers interested in understanding the outcomes of the environmentally embedded and socially constructed interactive behaviors that anthropologists study.

This project has broad impacts on policy associated with both the illicit drug economy, as well as future uses of ethnography as a research methodology. Current knowledge about illicit drug markets is informed by two distinct literatures. The majority of research involves large-scale studies using data collected administratively from law enforcement, and other indirect epidemiological indicators. This research focuses on understanding associations and outcomes of the illicit drug economy. On the other hand, ethnographic research has described roles within this economy, transactions, and how local illicit drug markets and organizations operate. Both research perspectives are informative; however, neither individually is equipped to link levels of analysis. Researching the local drug market as a Complex Adaptive System using ABM will allow research to scale-up results, conduct experiments, and generate outcomes previously unavailable using other methods. This knowledge will provide a new perspective for constructing and evaluating policies and interventions to effectively reduce the impact of these activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This three-year study made important intellectual contributions to the field of cultural anthropology, as well as to our broader understanding of how illegal drug markets operate to influence the lives of people who participate in them. The project advanced methods in cultural anthropology for developing computational social simulations. Specifically, it established a systematic approach for researchers who collect qualitative (and ethnographic) data to incorporate their findings into agent-based models. For this purpose, the project collected very detailed case-study data about how people who use heroin acquire drugs from their dealers and peers. In the war on drugs, the US has perpetually confronted challenges associated with how the illegal drug economy operates. Understanding these activities are also critical for the daily lives of people addicted, as well as for the well being of the general public. However, illegal drug markets are complex systems that involve dynamic interactions among many different “actors.” For researchers who study the social behaviors that occur within these settings, historically one of the most effective methods has involved ethnographic research.

Ethnography is the hallmark method of cultural anthropology and requires researchers develop considerable rapport with subjects, observing their daily activities, and conducting repeated open-ended interviews with them in the settings in which they live. This method is effectively employed to acquire a rich scientific understanding concerning how complex social systems function. It is also indispensable for understanding subject populations that otherwise might not participate in traditional social science research or when topics are too sensitive, stigmatizing, or deviant to assure valid results using conventional methods.

Although for decades "fieldwork-based" research has been vital to research on illegal drug markets, findings from such studies are typically very nuanced and only reported via highly detailed narratives. Our project developed an alternative approach by extracting information collected via fieldwork on interactive decision-making, beliefs, and behaviors of heroin users and then evaluating that data using a computational modeling approach. Using specialized computer software, we duplicated scenarios uncovered via our fieldwork using autonomous agents executing simple rules. With the products of interactions quantified in this manner, this project tested assumptions and observed outcomes that, while delineated clearly in narratives, remained otherwise impossible to observe or measure. For instance, many drug dealers want to remain hidden, and as a result an important way people acquire illegal drugs (heroin) is with the assistance of a peer who is already using a dealer. In other words, peers expand the capability of a heroin user to locate heroin. However, when people "buy" drugs in this manner, proceeds are often shared between the peer and the actual purchaser. This means that the cost of an illegal drug may be much greater than its retail price indicates. It also means social relationships between users have direct economic value and are critical to the operation of illegal drug markets. Although this finding emerged in a fairly straightforward manner within our dataset, and was compatible to what other researchers have discovered, quantifying its influence has been extremely complicated because of the dynamic and non-linear operation of this system. In other words, heroin users change their social networks, adapt their drug acquisition behaviors, and take advantage of opportunities and act to avoid arrest. The first simulation completed from our project investigated the nature of these indirectly mediated sale activities, demonstrating their influence on increasing and distributing the cost of heroin throughout the community of users.
